Detailed Description

< The QWidgets++ class library extends the CRaw widget by adding double buffering functionality. The double buffering is realized by using the PmMem... functions

Member Function Documentation

CRaw::STANDARD_CONSTRUCTORS ( CRaw )
 

int CRaw::setConnectFunction ( int(* connectFunction)(PtWidget_t *widget) )
 

Sets the connect function. This is the function that creates any regions needed by the widget (normally PtWidget does this for you)

int CRaw::setExtentFunction ( void(* extentFunction)(PtWidget_t *widget) )
 

Sets the extent function. This is the function that determines the exact size of the widget based on default values and/or the widget's position, size, margins, borders, and highlighting information

int CRaw::setInitFunction ( int(* initFunction)(PtWidget_t *widget) )
 

Sets the init function. This function is typically used by widgets that create children. It checks to ensure that all members used in a subsequent call to the extent function are correctly assigned.

int CRaw::setDrawFunction ( void(* drawFunction)(PtWidget_t *widget,PhTile_t *damage) )
 

Double buffering extension

void CRaw::enableDoubleBuffering ( )
 

void CRaw::disableDoubleBuffering ( )
 

int CRaw::isDoubleBufferingEnabled ( )
 

If double buffering is enabled, and if the functions startDoubleBufferDraw() / stopDoubleBufferDraw() are used, double buffering will be used to avoid flickering

int CRaw::startDoubleBufferDrawing ( )
 

Call this function in the draw function, before you start drawing the raw widgets contents. If double buffering is enabled, it will be drawn into memory The function returns -1 in case of error, e.g. the when the double buffer couldn't be created. Double buffering will be switched off in this case. You can still call stopDoubleBufferDrawing though, so there is no obligation to use this error flag.

Reimplemented in CRenderArea.

void CRaw::stopDoubleBufferDrawing ( )
 

The following functions select the format for the double buffer

void CRaw::setMemoryImageTypePaletteByte ( )
 

This format packs 1 pixel per byte, allowing up to 256 colors. This format indexes directly into the current palette; If no palette is set, the function chooses colors from the global palette; this may cause colors to look different on each system.

void CRaw::setMemoryImageTypeDirect888 ( )
 

This format packs each pixel into 3 bytes. Using this format, you can represent a full 24 bit color image. Here's the bit order: RRRR.RRRR.GGGG.GGGG.BBBB.BBBB
